p: It was reported that the EO of rhizome and leaf of Acorus gramineus displayed sedative and anticonvulsant properties and also anti-oxidative activity after fragrance inhalation [ 20]. Koo et al. [ 20] reported that pre-inhalation of the EO of Acorus gramineus markedly delayed the appearance of pentylenetetrazole-induced convulsion. Moreover, fragrance inhalation progressively prolonged the pentobarbital-induced sleeping time as the inhalation time was lengthened. This sedative effect after inhalation or oral administration of A. gramineus EO suggests that this oil may act on the CNS via the GABAergic system. The main components in the EO are β-asarone (40.3%), euasarone (17.0%) and α-euasarone (12.3%) [ 20].
